awd_titl_txt: Public Awareness of STEM and Advancing the Role of Women in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a U.S.-Asia regional workshop on how best to enhance public awareness of science and technology and advance women's participation in STEM. The meeting will convene a group of approximately 30 invited scholars and experts from the fields of Science, Technology & Society (STS), Women in STEM, and Science Popularization from the U.S. and 9 South Asian and Southeast Asian countries (Bangladesh, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Nepal, Pakistan, Singapore, Sri Lanka and Thailand). The meeting will utilize the wealth of data showing how STEM drives economic development and emphasize the growing appreciation that education in STEM must be targeted, not only to future STEM professionals in government and industry, but also to the general public. These developing Asian countries represent some of the most vibrant emerging economies in the world, and the U.S. can learn much from better understanding the opportunities and challenges these countries face in promoting STEM. Thus, this is a propitious time to gather information from them on how (and perhaps, whether), national STEM policies are affected by the public's awareness of STEM as a significant driver of economic growth. Also critical within these countries (and in the United States) are the challenges related to equity for women in STEM participation, employment, and leadership. This project will address the issue of advancement of women in the STEM education and workforce from a cross-national perspective. Through this interactive workshop, the project team will gather information on how the informal education and popularization of STEM may improve the participation of women in selected Asian countries as well as in the United States. It will address how to build a gender inclusive workforce that would lead to innovation much needed for both economic growth and social well-being. Drawing on lessons from data and experience, participants will craft suggested national and international strategies to promote public awareness and appreciation of STEM as important factors in economic development and societal well-being, with a particular focus on gender equity and inclusion. 

This Conference project will produce an up-to-date status report on issues of gender equity in STEM thorough a series of publications. Furthermore, this project will lead to establishment of partnerships within the STS and Science Popularization academic communities in Asian countries and the U.S. The proposed cross-national engagement will foster international research on gender in both the STEM  workplace and marketplace. Finally, the hybrid approaches to professional conference facilitation explored at this meeting have the  potential to significantly enhance how organizations across a variety of STEM disciplines might think about organizing and supporting professional collaboration and sharing in the future. Overall, this regional project is expected to trigger meaningful conversations and long term impacts on these issues among a large international group of scholars and practitioners. This project is jointly funded by the NSF programs in Science, Technology, and Society (STS), ADVANCE, and the Office of International Science and Engineering (OISE).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Public Awareness of STEM and Advancing the Role of Women in STEM project was a series of meetings which convened a group of approximately 40 Science Technology & Society (STS) and Popularization of Science experts from 9 South Asian and Southeast Asian countries (Bangladesh, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Nepal, Pakistan, Singapore, Sri Lanka and Thailand), plus the U.S., to discuss and seek international strategies for promoting public awareness and appreciation of STEM as important factors in economic development and societal well-being, with a particular focus on gender equity and inclusion. The cross-fertilization of ideas and sharing of efforts from this committed group of professionals helped to advance collective understanding of national STEM-equity policies, practices and research, and how these efforts could be collectively leveraged to affect the public's awareness of STEM as a significant driver of economic growth.

Originally planned as a 2? day, face-to-face meeting in Bangkok, Thailand, the Covid-19 pandemic forced project participants into an exclusively virtual format. Although not what any of the participants would have wished for, the vast majority embraced meeting virtually, and collectively worked to make these gatherings successful. Rather than a single meeting, the project ended up involving three days of large-group virtual meetings and dozens of small group virtual meetings, with participants divided between three working groups ? a Practice Working Group, Policy Working Group and Research Working Group.

Project evaluation revealed that this initiative successfully fostered learning and the building of new relationships and collaborations among participants. In particular, the project achieved its goal of fostering intranational and international collaboration between Science-Technology-Society and Popularization of Science professionals as well as its goal of identifying and examining opportunities, challenges, and barriers to participation of women (and girls) in STEM learning, participation, employment, and leadership. Given the significant, long-standing and systemic barriers that currently exist in the area of gender equity in STEM, it is not surprising that the project did not fully achieve its ambitious goal of crafting effective, self-sustaining models that support the public?s awareness, understanding and appreciation of STEM as significant forces for economic growth and societal well-being. There was, however, evidence to suggest that the project did make progress towards laying the foundations for achieving this goal in the future.

Intellectual Merit      This project specifically addressed the critical and globally wide-spread issue of how best to advance the role of women (and girls) in the STEM education and workforce. Project participants were able to shed further light on how the current disparities in the careers of women from different countries in STEM come about and are maintained. A major outcome of the project was highlighting and documenting the important role played by the informal education and popularization of STEM communities in helping to change these entrenched realities. Also pointed out by the project were current deficiencies in the gender-equity policies of virtually all of the ten participating countries, particularly for supporting efforts outside of primary and secondary schooling and beyond post-tertiary education. Also notable was the generation of a special issue of the journal American Behavioral Scientist which specifically addressed several critical Science-Technology-Society questions related to gender equity issues in the Asian context, including the challenge of overcoming initial interest and participation in STEM by younger women but the precipitous drop-off in this interest and participation that occurs as a consequence of the deep-rooted, paternalistic traditional values that exist in many Asian countries. Several of the framings and solutions proposed in this special issue provide powerful new insights and approaches for ameliorating these long-standing challenges.

Broader Impacts       This project significantly contributed to on-going efforts within the U.S. and around the world to counter historic patterns of gender inequity. A special, peer-reviewed issue of the international academic journal American Behavioral Scientist, aimed at the academic community, is helping to foster an enhanced dialogue around several key concerns related to this issue, with particular reference to the Asian context. In addition, the project was able to foster numerous cross-national collaborations and projects designed to build local, regional and even global capacity for improvement in the quality of STEM awareness, understanding and economic development. Finally, due to the necessities created by the Covid-19 pandemic, the project was forced to move to a completely virtual format. An unintended benefit of this shift was the opening up new possibilities and approaches to engaging international professionals in meaningful and substantive collaboration. Although traditional conferences involving face-to-face interactions are likely to remain important, the new, virtual approaches utilized in this project have the potential to significantly enhance how individuals and organizations across a variety of STEM disciplines might think about organizing and supporting professional collaboration and sharing in the future.
